Good suggestion, may I ask how I can download the emojis to the web assets folder during the build process? BTW, I found a link to https://www.webfx.com/tools/emoji-cheat-sheet/ in flexmark docs where I got those images. : )

@EricGao888 You can use `download-maven-plugin` to download these images and put them in the zeppelin-web module. 
See the example here https://github.com/apache/zeppelin/blob/master/spark/interpreter/pom.xml#L361

@Reamer I tried with setting IFS as "--conf". But its making things more worse. Bash is interpreting every character in "--conf" as a separator and breaking more things. 

We found a workaround around this issue by setting the spark.driver.extraJavaOptions for spark as below in zeppelin-env.sh
```export ZEPPELIN_INTP_JAVA_OPTS="-Dcom.example.env=production -Dcom.example.role=zeppelin"```

And we are setting spark.executor.extraJavaOptions in spark/conf/spark-defaults.conf file.

But I think its a bug in the interpreter.sh script in the first place. The previous snapshot version of zeppelin have a different interpreter.sh script. I tried to give more information in the Jira ticket that is in the description.

Also in another release of zeppelin it can again break if someone changes the way the variables are read into the array.
ping @cuspymd

Thrift 0.14.2 has been released.
This version also fixed a [regression in the Java library](https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/d604602064e9218cc1f0153a4f83dff22fa1b44e).
Maybe we should wait for this version.
Will merge if no more comment
@Reamer Do you have any more comment ? Otherwise I will merge it.

@nilroy I tried around a bit and found this [great explanation on Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/a/45201229)

I think the following solution can be used in our case. Tested at https://www.tutorialspoint.com/execute_bash_online.php
```
export SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS="$SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS --conf 'spark.driver.extraJavaOptions=-Dcom.example.env=production -Dcom.example.role=zeppelin' --conf mytest=myvalue"

readarray -td ''  SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS_ARRAY < <(awk '{ gsub(/--conf/,"\0--conf"); print; }' <<<"${SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS}--conf"); unset 'SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS_ARRAY[-1]'
declare -p SPARK_SUBMIT_OPTIONS_ARRAY;
```

What do you think?
Will merge if no more comment

Please test manually, it seems that the server does not start. Thank you for submitting the PR to close security gaps.

> Please test manually, it seems that the server does not start. Thank you for submitting the PR to close security gaps.

Looked fine when I tested. Anyway I will double check it.

My experience is that we can safely upgrade to version 9.4.40.v20210413 (which is also considered insecure). Any version after April causes a JSP startup error stating that /next is not defined. Jetty must have changed something to cause this issue.
CI is passed except the selenium test
LGTM

Thanks @sekikn  LGTM
I will merge it soon since it block the CI

> 
> 
> I am very interested in this PR. @cuspymd Thank you for your work.
> Should we also backport this to branch-0.9?

Are there any benefits to backporting it to branch-0.9?
And, at the time of rebase, there were conflicts with the modifications of @zjffdu, 
so it was difficult to merge. Backporting only these fixes would not be easy.

> My experience is that we can safely upgrade to version 9.4.40.v20210413 (which is also considered insecure). Any version after April causes a JSP startup error stating that /next is not defined. Jetty must have changed something to cause this issue.
I tried version 9.4.40.v20210413 and it did work. May I ask whether there's a way to make the 9.4.42.v20210604 version jetty compatible with zeppelin?  After all, the purpose for upgrading jetty is to solve the security problem.
Thanks for review @cuspymd  will merge it if no more comment
